text: I remember this from the 80s, the 90s, the 00s, and the 10s. While we're at it, they were all called the "decade of greed," too.

text: Perhaps you have the luxury. For a while anyway. I don't imagine it will remain a current or acceptable word for long anymore. And this one really isn't worth fighting for.
author: JasonKuznicki

text: As I said, it would be a positive good to give up this word even without the nazi implications. "Provider" is redundant, vague, and bureaucratic. It's an ugly word.
author: JasonKuznicki

text: It's one completely redundant newspeak-y word that has an unconscionable history. I am ashamed not to have known about it. I see much good about getting rid of it, and no drawbacks at all.
author: JasonKuznicki

text: First time I'd heard of it too. I am sorry, but I will definitely be avoiding this term in the future and urging others to do likewise. It's not worth being the brave contrarian when it just puts you in the company of nazis.
author: JasonKuznicki

text: Because you exercising your freedom of association is exactly like someone else arbitrarily restricting that same freedom.
author: JasonKuznicki

text: Good to know they're ... (checks notes) ... paying their fair share?
